A **bullwhip** is a type of [weapon](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is made of [leather](/wiki/Leather "Leather").

[ ]

## Generation

All [Archeologists](/wiki/Archeologist "Archeologist") start with a +2 bullwhip.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

[Balrogs](/wiki/Balrog "Balrog") are [always generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a bullwhip, and [horned devils](/wiki/Horned_devil "Horned devil") also have a 25% chance of being spawned with a bullwhip. In the balrog's case, the order of monster weapon preference means they will never wield it unless they somehow lose their guaranteed [broadsword](/wiki/Broadsword "Broadsword").[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

[Player monsters](/wiki/Player_monster "Player monster") have a chance of receiving a bullwhip as a random melee weapon; [archeologists](/wiki/Archeologist_\(player_monster\) "Archeologist (player monster)") have a 50% chance of their melee weapon being replaced with a bullwhip.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

## Whip skill

| Whip   |                                                                       |
| ------ | --------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Max    | [Role](/wiki/Role "Role")                                             |
| Basic  | - [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger"), [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist") |
| Expert | * [Archeologist](/wiki/Archeologist "Archeologist")                   |

Both bullwhips and [rubber hoses](/wiki/Rubber_hose "Rubber hose") use the **whip skill**.

## Description

A bullwhip is ineffective against [thick-skinned](/wiki/Thick-skinned "Thick-skinned") monsters, and can be [applied](/wiki/Applied "Applied") by a [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") to snap it in a direction and perform a number of special tricks:[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

- Attack a monster normally.
- [Disarm an enemy](#Disarming).
- [Retrieving items](#Picking_up_items).
- Wrap around [furniture](/wiki/Furniture "Furniture"), a [boulder](/wiki/Boulder "Boulder"), or a [large](/wiki/Large "Large") monster to pull yourself out of a [pit](/wiki/Pit "Pit").

The success of these tricks depends on the hero's [dexterity](/wiki/Dexterity "Dexterity"), whether they are an [Archaeologist](/wiki/Archaeologist "Archaeologist"), and whether they are [fumbling](/wiki/Fumbling "Fumbling"). A hero who is not an Archaeologist must have a dexterity higher than 14 to be considered proficient - whip tricks will always fail unless the hero is proficient.

*NetHack* makes the following assumptions to determine what to do when a whip is applied:

- If the hero is in a pit, then they are attempting to get out of the pit unless they are applying the whip towards a small monster, in which case it is assumed that they are trying to attack it.
- If the hero is in a pit, and the monster is wielding a weapon, then they are attempting to disarm a monster.
- If the hero is in a pit and applies the whip towards a monster without a wielded weapon, then they are attempting to hit the monster.
- The hero cannot perform any tricks (besides attacking monsters) if they are [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused") or [engulfed](/wiki/Engulfed "Engulfed").

### Disarming

If applying a bullwhip at an enemy disarms them, the disarmed weapon may end up on the floor at the enemy's feet, on the floor at the hero's feet, or in the hero's inventory, depending on a 'proficiency' check. Disarming a pet does not reduce its [tameness](/wiki/Tameness "Tameness"), but disarming a peaceful monster will anger it.

If the target is wielding a non-cursed weapon and you succeed, disarming does not break [weaponless](/wiki/Weaponless "Weaponless") conduct. Trying to disarm non-pets can break the conduct because the hero always has a 1⁄10 chance of attacking instead, and you can only [decline](/wiki/Options#safe_pet "Options") for pets.

Disarming is the only trick that whip-wielding monsters can use, and functions similarly to the same trick for the hero, with the following exceptions:[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

- An [iron ball](/wiki/Iron_ball "Iron ball") is too heavy to be disarmed.
- A horned devil or other [silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver")-hating monster using a whip to pull a silver item from the hero's hands will never pull the item into its inventory, instead dropping it at the hero's feet.

### Picking up items

Applying a bullwhip down towards an item while the hero is [riding](/wiki/Riding "Riding") or [levitating](/wiki/Levitating "Levitating") will pick it up off the floor, including out of a [pool](/wiki/Pool "Pool") or [moat](/wiki/Moat "Moat") of water or [lava](/wiki/Lava "Lava") if applicable. When applying a whip downwards while riding a steed, there is always a 20-33% chance of hitting the steed instead.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Snagging items from the bottom of water or lava using a bullwhip is no longer possible, and in the case of lava can burn or even destroy the whip.

### Riding

Applying the bullwhip to snap it at a steed while riding will cause it to [gallop](/wiki/Gallop "Gallop"), temporarily increasing its speed but reducing its tameness - this includes hitting the steed while trying to pick up an item off the floor.

## Strategy

Bullwhips are viable utility items, primarily sought after for their ability to pry desirable weapons out of the hands of a [humanoid](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid") pet and/or forcing it to pick up and wield a different (usually better) weapon. While disarming thankfully does not constitute pet abuse, you will anger any peaceful monsters you disarm - using a bullwhip to grab the [Minetown](/wiki/Minetown "Minetown") [watch captain](/wiki/Watch_captain "Watch captain")'s [silver saber](/wiki/Silver_saber "Silver saber") is probably a [Bad Idea](/wiki/Bad_Idea "Bad Idea") if you expect to make off with it scot-free. Most monsters can wield bullwhips, but will prefer most other weapons over them, as indicated in the case of the balrog - they will still wield a bullwhip over some weapons, such as [quarterstaves](/wiki/Quarterstaves "Quarterstaves") and [daggers](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger").

Heroes looking to levitate frequently (e.g., [Barbarians](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian") using [The Heart of Ahriman](/wiki/The_Heart_of_Ahriman "The Heart of Ahriman")) will also want to carry a bullwhip with them in order to reach items on the floor, as well as those retrieving loot or thrown weapons from [moats](/wiki/Moat "Moat") - since this is reliant on dexterity rather than weapon skill, all roles can make use of this through varying amounts of stat exercise.

***Beware:*** snagging a wielded [footrice](/wiki/Footrice "Footrice") [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") from a monster with a bullwhip causes it to make contact with the hero's hands, carrying the risk of [stoning](/wiki/Stoning "Stoning") them, although picking up a footrice corpse from the ground does not.[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)[\[8\]](#cite_note-8) [Flight](/wiki/Flight "Flight") will not allow you to pick up items from moats this way unless you are also levitating.

Bullwhips can be used as an aid for [riding](/wiki/Riding "Riding") players - in addition to increasing a steed's movement speed, all roles capable of advancing the whip skill can also advance the riding skill to basic. While the former can also be achieved by [kicking](/wiki/Kick "Kick") your steed, rendering the bullwhip somewhat redundant, it is still useful for picking up items off the floor while unskilled if you encounter one early enough.

## History

The bullwhip is introduced in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

In [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") and previous versions, including some variants based on those versions, the bullwhip is often used to reliably disarm a [figurine](/wiki/Figurine "Figurine") [Archon](/wiki/Archon "Archon") and obtain [Demonbane](/wiki/Demonbane "Demonbane") - monsters generated by figurines still spawn with their normal starting inventory. The bullwhip was also involved in a few [now-fixed bugs](/wiki/Bugs_in_NetHack_3.4.3 "Bugs in NetHack 3.4.3"):

- A player [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into a xorn cannot pick up items in pits, and could not fall into them; the primary workaround was to obtain levitation and apply a bullwhip downward towards the pit in question. This was bug C343-16, and was fixed on January 27, 2004.
- [Sunsword](/wiki/Sunsword "Sunsword") would continue to remain lit if snatched out of a monster's hands with a bullwhip. This was bug C343-106, and was fixed on July 15, 2005.
- Applying a bullwhip while stunned or confused and at an edge of the map may cause a panic or crash. This was bug C343-383, and fixed prior to [the next version's](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0") release; the commits containing the fixes was pushed on February 23, 2009.[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)

## Origin

The Archaeologist's starting bullwhip, along with the leather jacket and fedora, is one of the many trademark accessories of [Indiana Jones](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indiana_Jones "wikipedia:Indiana Jones"), the titular character and star of a franchise of movies made by George Lucas and Steven Spielberg. Jones in turn is based on the heroes of 1930s pulp serials and inspired the Archaeologist role.

## Messages

- Why beat a dead horse?

  You applied a bullwhip downwards while flying or levitating, on a square containing a horse corpse.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), an Archeologist [wielding](/wiki/Wield "Wield") a bullwhip will not fall through [trap doors](/wiki/Trap_door "Trap door"); this does not require a dexterity check. Objects on the trap door might still be shoved through.[\[11\]](#cite_note-11) The [Undead Slayer](/wiki/Undead_Slayer "Undead Slayer") has a 25% chance of starting with a +2 bullwhip; this is derived from the *Castlevania* franchise, where the whip is frequently used by the Belmont clan.

Bullwhips tend to see more use in SLASH'EM - players with powerful humanoid pets will want to enchant that pet's weapon so that it can take on late-game foes that [need enchanted weapons of a certain level to hit](/wiki/Need_%2Bx_weapon_to_hit "Need +x weapon to hit"). Additionally, [vampire](/wiki/Vampire_\(starting_race_in_SLASH%27EM\) "Vampire (starting race in SLASH'EM)") heroes will want a bullwhip and a source of levitation to retrieve items in moats or pits.

#### Messages

- But thanks to your trusty whip ... You don't fall in.

  A trap door opened under you, but you were an Archeologist wielding a bullwhip, preventing you from falling through.

### SlashTHEM

In addition to SLASH'EM examples, [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") adds [Liontamer](/index.php?title=Liontamer\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Liontamer (page does not exist)"), an artifact bullwhip acts as the first [sacrifice gift](/wiki/Sacrifice_gift "Sacrifice gift") for [Zookeepers](/wiki/Zookeeper "Zookeeper"). Liontamer has +5 to-hit and +8 damage versus [felines](/wiki/Feline "Feline").

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), an archeologist [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") can sometimes be found under a boulder trap, and may be accompanied by the former adventurer's bullwhip. The [Ruins of Moria](/wiki/Ruins_of_Moria "Ruins of Moria") branch always has an uncursed fireproof bullwhip, wielded by the unique [balrog](/wiki/Balrog "Balrog") [Durin's Bane](/wiki/Durin%27s_Bane "Durin's Bane").

### dNetHack

[dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") also features Durin's Bane, this time as the [quest nemesis](/wiki/Quest_nemesis "Quest nemesis") of the [dwarven](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)") [Noble](/wiki/Noble "Noble"); it generates with a cursed +9 bullwhip.

## Encyclopedia entry

"Good," he said and, unbelievably, smiled at me, a smirk like  
a round of rotted cheese. "What did your keeper use on you?  
A bullwhip?"

\[ Melusine, by Sarah Monette ]

A '''bullwhip''' is a type of [[weapon]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is made of [[leather]].

==Generation==
All [[Archeologist]]s start with a +2 bullwhip.{{refsrc|src/u_init.c|29|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

[[Balrog]]s are [[Monster starting inventory|always generated with]] a bullwhip, and [[horned devil]]s also have a 25% chance of being spawned with a bullwhip. In the balrog's case, the order of monster weapon preference means they will never wield it unless they somehow lose their guaranteed [[broadsword]].{{refsrc|src/weapon.c|639|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

[[Player monster]]s have a chance of receiving a bullwhip as a random melee weapon; [[Archeologist (player monster)|archeologists]] have a 50% chance of their melee weapon being replaced with a bullwhip.{{refsrc|src/mplayer.c|165|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

==Whip skill==
{{whip skill table}}

Both bullwhips and [[rubber hose]]s use the '''whip skill'''.

==Description==
A bullwhip is ineffective against [[thick-skinned]] monsters, and can be [[applied]] by a [[hero]] to snap it in a direction and perform a number of special tricks:{{refsrc|src/apply.c|2635|nethack=3.6.7|comment=function use_whip}}

* Attack a monster normally.
* [[#Disarming|Disarm an enemy]].
* [[#Picking up items|Retrieving items]].
* Wrap around [[furniture]], a [[boulder]], or a [[large]] monster to pull yourself out of a [[pit]].

The success of these tricks depends on the hero's [[dexterity]], whether they are an [[Archaeologist]], and whether they are [[fumbling]]. A hero who is not an Archaeologist must have a dexterity higher than 14 to be considered proficient - whip tricks will always fail unless the hero is proficient.

''NetHack'' makes the following assumptions to determine what to do when a whip is applied:

* If the hero is in a pit, then they are attempting to get out of the pit unless they are applying the whip towards a small monster, in which case it is assumed that they are trying to attack it.
* If the hero is in a pit, and the monster is wielding a weapon, then they are attempting to disarm a monster.
* If the hero is in a pit and applies the whip towards a monster without a wielded weapon, then they are attempting to hit the monster.
* The hero cannot perform any tricks (besides attacking monsters) if they are [[confused]] or [[engulfed]].

===Disarming===
If applying a bullwhip at an enemy disarms them, the disarmed weapon may end up on the floor at the enemy's feet, on the floor at the hero's feet, or in the hero's inventory, depending on a 'proficiency' check. Disarming a pet does not reduce its [[tameness]], but disarming a peaceful monster will anger it.

If the target is wielding a non-cursed weapon and you succeed, disarming does not break [[weaponless]] conduct. Trying to disarm non-pets can break the conduct because the hero always has a {{frac|10}} chance of attacking instead, and you can only [[Options#safe_pet|decline]] for pets.

Disarming is the only trick that whip-wielding monsters can use, and functions similarly to the same trick for the hero, with the following exceptions:{{refsrc|src/muse.c|1910|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=case MUSE_BULLWHIP}}

* An [[iron ball]] is too heavy to be disarmed.
* A horned devil or other [[silver]]-hating monster using a whip to pull a silver item from the hero's hands will never pull the item into its inventory, instead dropping it at the hero's feet.

===Picking up items===
Applying a bullwhip down towards an item while the hero is [[riding]] or [[levitating]] will pick it up off the floor, including out of a [[pool]] or [[moat]] of water or [[lava]] if applicable. When applying a whip downwards while riding a steed, there is always a 20-33% chance of hitting the steed instead.{{refsrc|src/apply.c|2698|nethack=3.6.7}}

{{upcoming|NetHack 3.7.0|Snagging items from the bottom of water or lava using a bullwhip is no longer possible, and in the case of lava can burn or even destroy the whip.}}

===Riding===
Applying the bullwhip to snap it at a steed while riding will cause it to [[gallop]], temporarily increasing its speed but reducing its tameness - this includes hitting the steed while trying to pick up an item off the floor. 

==Strategy==
Bullwhips are viable utility items, primarily sought after for their ability to pry desirable weapons out of the hands of a [[humanoid]] pet and/or forcing it to pick up and wield a different (usually better) weapon. While disarming thankfully does not constitute pet abuse, you will anger any peaceful monsters you disarm - using a bullwhip to grab the [[Minetown]] [[watch captain]]'s [[silver saber]] is probably a [[Bad Idea]] if you expect to make off with it scot-free. Most monsters can wield bullwhips, but will prefer most other weapons over them, as indicated in the case of the balrog - they will still wield a bullwhip over some weapons, such as [[quarterstaves]] and [[dagger]]s.

Heroes looking to levitate frequently (e.g., [[Barbarian]]s using [[The Heart of Ahriman]]) will also want to carry a bullwhip with them in order to reach items on the floor, as well as those retrieving loot or thrown weapons from [[moat]]s - since this is reliant on dexterity rather than weapon skill, all roles can make use of this through varying amounts of stat exercise.

'''''Beware:''''' snagging a wielded [[footrice]] [[corpse]] from a monster with a bullwhip causes it to make contact with the hero's hands, carrying the risk of [[stoning]] them, although picking up a footrice corpse from the ground does not.{{refsrc|src/apply.c|2714|nethack=3.6.7|comment=call pickup_object with telekinesis TRUE}}{{refsrc|src/apply.c|2849|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} [[Flight]] will not allow you to pick up items from moats this way unless you are also levitating.

Bullwhips can be used as an aid for [[riding]] players - in addition to increasing a steed's movement speed, all roles capable of advancing the whip skill can also advance the riding skill to basic. While the former can also be achieved by [[kick]]ing your steed, rendering the bullwhip somewhat redundant, it is still useful for picking up items off the floor while unskilled if you encounter one early enough.

==History==
The bullwhip is introduced in [[NetHack 3.0.0]].

In [[NetHack 3.4.3]] and previous versions, including some variants based on those versions, the bullwhip is often used to reliably disarm a [[figurine]] [[Archon]] and obtain [[Demonbane]] - monsters generated by figurines still spawn with their normal starting inventory. The bullwhip was also involved in a few [[Bugs in NetHack 3.4.3|now-fixed bugs]]:

* A player [[polymorph]]ed into a xorn cannot pick up items in pits, and could not fall into them; the primary workaround was to obtain levitation and apply a bullwhip downward towards the pit in question. This was bug C343-16, and was fixed on January 27, 2004.
* [[Sunsword]] would continue to remain lit if snatched out of a monster's hands with a bullwhip. This was bug C343-106, and was fixed on July 15, 2005.
* Applying a bullwhip while stunned or confused and at an edge of the map may cause a panic or crash. This was bug C343-383, and fixed prior to [[NetHack 3.6.0|the next version's]] release; the commits containing the fixes was pushed on February 23, 2009.<ref>[https://sourceforge.net/p/nethack/NetHack/ci/e11c136bc9d5e254ab97fa533d32cc8f25c4e53e Commit e11c13, NetHack 3.4.3 @ SourceForge]</ref><ref>[https://sourceforge.net/p/nethack/NetHack/ci/b71b3e920af4b143bdfcb0b443de68343f099235 Commit b71b3e, NetHack 3.4.3 @ SourceForge]</ref>

==Origin==
The Archaeologist's starting bullwhip, along with the leather jacket and fedora, is one of the many trademark accessories of [[wikipedia:Indiana Jones|Indiana Jones]], the titular character and star of a franchise of movies made by George Lucas and Steven Spielberg. Jones in turn is based on the heroes of 1930s pulp serials and inspired the Archaeologist role.

==Messages==
{{message|Why beat a dead horse?|You applied a bullwhip downwards while flying or levitating, on a square containing a horse corpse.}}

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], an Archeologist [[wield]]ing a bullwhip will not fall through [[trap door]]s; this does not require a dexterity check. Objects on the trap door might still be shoved through.{{refsrc|trap.c|359|version=SLASH'EM_0.0.7E7F2}} The [[Undead Slayer]] has a 25% chance of starting with a +2 bullwhip; this is derived from the ''Castlevania'' franchise, where the whip is frequently used by the Belmont clan.

Bullwhips tend to see more use in SLASH'EM - players with powerful humanoid pets will want to enchant that pet's weapon so that it can take on late-game foes that [[Need +x weapon to hit|need enchanted weapons of a certain level to hit]]. Additionally, [[Vampire (starting race in SLASH'EM)|vampire]] heroes will want a bullwhip and a source of levitation to retrieve items in moats or pits.

====Messages====
{{message|But thanks to your trusty whip ... You don't fall in.|A trap door opened under you, but you were an Archeologist wielding a bullwhip, preventing you from falling through.}}

===SlashTHEM===
In addition to SLASH'EM examples, [[SlashTHEM]] adds [[Liontamer]], an artifact bullwhip acts as the first [[sacrifice gift]] for [[Zookeeper]]s. Liontamer has +5 to-hit and +8 damage versus [[feline]]s.

===UnNetHack===
In [[UnNetHack]], an archeologist [[corpse]] can sometimes be found under a boulder trap, and may be accompanied by the former adventurer's bullwhip. The [[Ruins of Moria]] branch always has an uncursed fireproof bullwhip, wielded by the unique [[balrog]] [[Durin's Bane]].

===dNetHack===
[[dNetHack]] also features Durin's Bane, this time as the [[quest nemesis]] of the [[Dwarf (starting race)|dwarven]] [[Noble]]; it generates with a cursed +9 bullwhip.
